comments.commentBody: While most students from Babson will pursue business careers, it is far from the case that most will choose to maximize career earnings. Most of my ivy league friends went on to investment banking in the 2000s, yet I (as a Babson grad) chose to pursue a career in public education and went on to a PhD program at Columbia. While I agree that it is a dangerous trend to pursue money over, say, learning, I wouldn't belittle Babson for being Money's most visible rep for its rankings. It's highly rigorous liberal arts program is what taught me to be different from other business people and what led me to believing that I can use my skills for the greater good. Babson teaches students to think independently and entrepreneurially, and students have both been highly successful in business and elsewhere with those mindsets. And while I would love for those who do not know what Babson represents to learn more about the school other than just saying "Oh It's a business school," I realize that people will often speak in stereotypes rather than learning the truth in discourse.

W.A. Spitzer:

You build and repair infrastructure employing robots and very few human overseers. You improve public education in part by standardizing and elevating its quality through MOOCs (Massively Open Online Courses) moderated by our best educators, cutting countless less-gifted teachers out of the loop. Basic research certainly can be performed anywhere, and, in time, much of it can be automated. Healthcare and food distribution as well can be automated to a far greater degree than at present, and it's getting there. Housing? Robots again.

I can't imagine that any likely solution to the challenges I've outlined will involve LESS spending and government; but your response fails to erect a single barrier to my reasoning.

Trump reminds me of a description of the appealing leader, as described in Le Bon's 'The Crowd', intuitively sensing that what the crowd wants, what the crowd needs, is a loud and insistent voice repeating the same mantra again and again, appealing to the crowd's basest emotions.

Le Bon sagely noted that large aggregations of people are not attracted to the leader who is the most balanced, intelligent and sensible, but to the one who incites their feelings. Trump plays that card very well, constantly appealing to fears of invasion from Mexico and the Middle East. Fears of a government said to be corrupt and inept, of leaders he and other Republicans say have failed, like that Kenyan Barack Obama.

Americans like their leaders bold and their leadership bolder, regardless of how ludicrous or dangerous the ideas or the actions. Many like the man or woman who speaks their language, as with G.W. Bush, a man they'd like to have a beer with.

Frequently I hear people who are right wing oriented. Their comment on how the country is being run is composed of this slander promulgated by the conservatives.

By the way, just what is a conservative? It seems as far as I can tell, whatever these nihilists think it is. Everyone from biker gangs, religious nuts, small business men, and neer do well wage earners, all with a ring in their nose so they can be led around by likes of Trump.
Disingenuous Douthat deserves to be dismissed with a dollop of Trumpian disdain.

Is Kristof incapable of seeing what Trump represents? He is merely a vessel for the heartfelt bitterness many Americans are feeling over our failed foreign entanglements.

Just think:
> We have over sold our economy to foreign slavers for a surfeit of cheap goods at the expense of gainful employment for many.
> We have over stayed our welcome overseas by naively expecting our exceptional form of democracy to be welcomed with open arms.
> We have over extended our military with our interventionism and protection of our alleged allies, these efforts being ungratefully spurned by many who could not only care less, but are turning against us and each other.

For good or bad, expect this country to be entering a period of isolationism with elements of nativism and xenophobia.

Given that, Kristof is dreaming if he thinks Americans are willing to continue our post-WW II era of internationalism. Rather, expect a post-2016 America to be more akin to post-WW I where the nation rejected the League of Nations and turned inward.

This country will continue to be a beacon on a hill. Only now, that beacon will be guarded behind the walls of fortress America, its gates closed to many.

Test scores should only be a side thought. I have two successful daughters both with graduate degrees. My eldest had the same 4.5 GPA with multiple AP classes as my youngest daughter. The difference was daughter 1 had timed test anxiety and scored just over average at 1200 old SAT while daughter 2, although a perfectionist also, scored 250 points higher. My first got turned down at Amherst while daughter 2 was feted there as well as at several Ivies, one of which she graduated from. Both equally succeeded, one in medicine and one as a budget analyst, and both are highly successful in their professions. Perhaps universities should look at recommendations as well as face to face interviews to gain insight. Weigh these as importantly as test scores. Mine were lucky to have drive and support; others just as talented but perhaps from less advantaged backgrounds need a more humanistic holistic look as they apply to college.

President Obama came into office with the worst recession in 80 years, two disasterous wars, no progress on climate change, and has had to contend with concerted efforts to demean , discredit and block him. The country is better off than it was, but Dowd continues her cheap shots.  She has no credibility, especially after she ate an entire cannabis-infused candy bar and seemed surprised at the negative effects.

Maureen has been doing a fine job of that herself as of late. Her ceaseless haranguing of the President does not offer insight, or even a counter view. It's just misplaced anger. One suspects Maureen, and her Tea Party brother Kevin, are no longer so far apart in their beliefs.  I loved re-reading the opening statement from Kevin's latest diatribe this past November, "While liberals and the mainstream media may regard the myriad Republican presidential candidates as a “house of crazies,” I see an embarrassment of riches. It is the ultimate irony that the Republican field blows the Democrats away on one of their favorite topics — diversity.". Apparently, they also "blow the Democrats away" on discussing genitalia size. Gotta love them Dowds.
Trump's work is incomplete: he hasn't yet made a monkey of Dowd.  Yes, she has it coming.

Over the past few days, I think I have read enough frustrated Bernie supporter comments (my personal thoughts included), and enough NYT articles that I still swear slant the wording to Hillary Clinton's favor. I am glad I was able to vote for Bernie in my state's primary on Tuesday, and I am doing my best to convince myself to vote for Hillary in November should the premonitions end up true. I would really like to see Bernie stay in and be represented well, unlike some Clinton supporters who seem to believe, and hope that he will get demolished in some upcoming major primaries/caucuses. I think the stronger Bernie shows, the more Hillary will be pressed to address certain issues and policies.

As for the Republicans, I am far more concerned with someone like Cruz representing the US as president than I am with Trump as I find deeply "religious" individuals in power to be a very scary thing. However, and possibly following from that very thing, I also find the probability of Cruz winning a presidential general election considerably lower than I do Trump.
I, too, wonder how Sanders is going to lure minority voters from Trump.
